newsitem.title: USA: Rallying US crude prices sustain sharp gains late.
newsitem.headline: Rallying US crude prices sustain sharp gains late.

text.p: U.S. cash crude prices staged a rally Thursday, pushing outright benchmark crudes above $20.00 a barrel due to a sustained technical push higher on the NYMEX futures market.

June West Texas Intermediate/Cushing was around 70 cents higher at $20.30-40 a barrel late in the day, pulling even with July WTI and eliminating a weeks-old discount the prompt month held to the second month.
Paper market gains were underpinned by a jolt higher in gasoline values, amid bullish sentiment for prompt fundamentals.
News also played a role Thursday in the crude rally, though some traders shrugged off developments.
Earlier in the day, OPEC President Libyan Oil Minister Abdullah Salem al-Badri said he expected the group to roll over its 25.03 million barrels per day (bpd) quota at the next OPEC meeting in June.
Al-Badri spoke in Iran at an OPEC ministerial meeting where seven of the group's members agreed to push for compliance to current quotas in an effort to boost world prices.
Late news also aided outrights, with Washington stating it would push the United Nations to enforce sanctions against international airflights by Libya.
Tripoli is banned from such flights for not handing over supsected terrorists thought to be responsible for the Lockerbie bombing in 1988 of a Pan Am jet.
Libyan leader Muammar Gaddafi reportedly traveled to Niger Thursday to lead Muslim prayers.

In the markets, crude traders said domestic grade barrels continued to pace a steady course for most sectors, though West Texas Sour/Midland returned to weaker differentials after rallying higher on Wednesday.
"It looks like people are playing around in the sour market, we were down to around a $1.30-35 discount on Wednesday but we're right back out to $1.60 today," said a Texas cash trader.
Late talk put WTS/Midland at minus $1.60-55 to the June WTI/Cushing, with Eugene Island talked around the same levels.
Light Louisiana Sweet/St. James was still at a three cents premium to the benchmark as the day ended. The only confirmed deals for LLS were at that mark, traders said.
A lack of Brent offerings in the U.S. Gulf allowed LLS to remain at a positive price to WTI.
"Last month people were comfortable delivering Brent to the Merc (NYMEX), but that's not a viable alternative with Dated (Brent) hanging around 25 cents," said a cash dealer.
Traders also noted that sizable chunks of North Sea and West African barrels were headed to Far East destinations due to sharp shrinkage of Brent-Dubai spreads.
July Brent-Dubai was pegged around plus 90-95 cents Thursday, some 30-40 cents lower than recent days.
